Hall Announces Tuition Hike
At Student Council Meeting
BY BRUCE ALPERT

Dean Joseph Hall explains the latest tuition increase to the SC.

Joseph Hall, Dean of Academic Services, announced to
the Student Council Wednesday
night that tuition for graduate
and undergraduate students of
Johns Hopkins would rise 14
percent over last year's to
$6,700 for the 1982-1983 academic year.
Dean Hall, who presented
the tuition figures to the Council, attributed the tuition increase to inflation and the
Reagan budget cuts in funds for
education. In formulating the
increase, Dean Hall said that
consideration was given not only
to the needs of those students
already enrolled at Johns Hopkins, but also to those of the
prospective freshman class.
This coming year's increase
represents a smaller percentage
increase than last year's, which

was in excess of 15 percent.
Hall also stated that Johns
Hopkins' proposed tuition hike
is "in the ballpark" with many
other schools of its type, which
he said are planning tuition
increases of 10 to 15 percent in
the coming year.
Hall also said that the
University dollar content of
many existing financial aid
packages would also rise, but he
was unsure what the net effect
of such increases would be. In
terms of outside aid, Hall said,
"We won't know how much
money we will be getting from
the Federal Government until
the mid-summer."
The proposed tuition increase will go to the University
trustees for approval on Feb. 22.

BY PAUL BRUNETTA

BG&ERaisesRates
Baltimore Gas and Electric customers will be hit with
another increase in fuel costs. BG&E requested $199 million in
revenues, but only received $99.2 million, the largest rate increase
in the company's history. What this means to the consumer is
that the average electricity user's bill will rise $3.70 while the
average gas user will pay $2.40 per month.
The State PuPlic Service Commission's decision means the
average customer's monthly bill for 600 kilowatt hours of electricity will jump by 9.2 percent to $42.27. Gas bills for 90 therms
will increase $2.41 to $45.95— an additional 4.9 percent.
To lighten this load, the customer's base monthly charge
has been reduced. The charge will drop from $4.14 to $2.69 a
month for electricity and from $5.02 to $2.85 for gas, a decrease
to help the poor.
Dr. Matthew Tayback, Director of the State Office on
Aging, is afraid that higher energy rates and aid cutbacks will
force senior citizens to choose "between the cost of drugs, food
and fuel." At the same time, the cost of public services and
Medicare copayment fees will increase. President Reagan has also
proposed a $9 million cut in energy assistance aid to the state.

Video Game Legislation
Donald P. Hutchinson, the Baltimore County Executive,
submitted a bill to the County Council on Tuesday to restrict the
operation of video games in designated locations. His proposal
permits the games in all three commercial zones, but bars them
from convenience stores not located in town centers or community core districts.
Civic leaders have expressed their concern that video
games operating in conveience stores are a "magnet for gangs"
and undesirables. The BILC allows a maximum of nine machines
in bars, bowling alleys, hotels, motels, and restaurants in addition
to arcades in malls and other commercial areas.

The Dawning Of An Era:
Selective Education?
This week's decision by Wesleyan
University to begin admitting only those
students who are able to pay tuition should
jolt out of insensitivity anyone with
lingering doubts about the seriousness of
government cuts in financial aid.
It's time to remember that the cuts
are the work of one administration, and
that election year 1984 could conceivably
see some of that work undone. For while
it may be that the cuts have performed
some long-overdue trimming of domestic
spending, things have reached the point
where a basic American ideal—the opportunity for advancement via education—is
not merely being threatened but eliminated. It is not simply that the very poor
are losing their shot at quality higher
education, an evil implicit in the cuts from
the outset; the category of the victimized
is growing to include those in higher
economic brackets. Hopkins, for example,
while it has pledged itself not to join
Wesleyan in what appears to be a trend, has
announced a 14 percent tuition hike for
next year. Couple this with the 10 percent
cut in financial aid instituted by the
University this year, and you find that the
student in need of aid is facing what
amounts to a 25 percent jump in tuition.

Thus, while Hopkins may not deny admission to such a student, it very probably will
not be able to extend him the money he
needs to come here.
The point is that the Reagan cuts
have acquired an inexorable media image as
"the beginning of a new era," the end of
the New Deal. While the cuts undeniably
are the beginning of a necessary era of
budget austerity, they must not be allowed
to roll back some of the basic rights safeguarded by the so-called New Deal era.
Perhaps the most important of these rights
is the opportunity for quality higher
education, for a democracy is not a democracy without this most basic form of equal
opportunity.
We are just now starting to hear
about further cuts being contemplated by
the Reagan administration. How much
further can they go before almost no one
can afford a higher education? The first
round of cuts may not have affected many
people you or I know here at Hopkins, but
the next round most certainly will. It
could even be us. And if it's not, we still
don't want to be the last generation of
Americans who had the luxury of expecting to complete a college education.

Attempted Coup In Spain:
One Student's Perspective
Af',..r completing almost six months of my junior
year abroad, I had come to expect almost anything.
After all, the Spanish police had already stopped and
interrogated me as a suspected pickpocket in the Madrid
Metro; a traveling companion and I hac'been jumped by a
group of teenage Moroccan boys as we meandered
through the labyrinths of the Fez medina; and countless
numbers of strangers had accosted me to offer wide
varieties of sex and drugs. Nevertheless, the attempted
coup d'etat that startled Madrid last February 23 presented a surprise I was not prepared to deal with.

by Martin Carlson
At five o'ciocic in the afternoon on that day, the
Prado Museum closed its doors, and my art history class
in the El Graco rooms ended. Since the weather was
already fairly warm and the Castilian sky was as blue as
ever, a friend and I opted to take the your walk back to
our respective dormitories instead of suffocating in the
Metro. We headed uphill past the Cortes (the Spanis
Parliament), down the Gran Via (the Main Drag), then
over to the Ciudad Universitaria (the University of
Madrid's campus). Before separating, we stood on the
corner in front of the Minesterio del Aire (Air Force
Headquarters) to talk for about fifteen minutes.
It was about seven when I finally arrived home to
my dormitory room and buried my nose in a fat Spanish
novel about a provocative adulteress. I figured that I
could finish the description of the Don Juan type who
seduced her before I ate dinner at nine thirty.
I had just become settled on my bed when in
barged my friend Pablo, who instantly destroyed my
Jabbering in almost incomprehensible
tranquility.
Spanish, he reported that a right-wing Guardia Civil
(Spanish paramilitary) group led by Lieutenant Colonel
Antonio Tejero had burst into the Cortes chamber of
representatives while the elected officials were voting on
the nomination of Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo for president.
The Guardia's intention: to overthrow the Spanish
government. I believed not a word Pablo said, since my
Spanish buddies were forever trying to pull my leg; yet
he convinced me to listen to the radio broadcasts so that
I could verify the report myself.
Hearing was believing, but all of us that had
gathered around the tiny radio remained extremely
confused. Many students expected all forms of communication to be cut off, yet even in the Cortes itself
both a television camera and a microphone remained to
record the events for the Spanish people.
Reacting like the typically naive Yankee, I
immediately proposed running down to the Cortes to
investigate the situation; but the Spaniards rejected such
rash stupidity. In fact, it was as if they had sixth sense
of what to do in a state of siege. Most of the guys in my
dormitory attempted to telephone their homes in the
provinces to discover if the Guardia Civil had seized
control outside the capital. Those fortunate enough to
own cars filled them with gas and packed suitcases so
they would be able to escape the city if violence were to
erupt. Not a soul dared step outside the confines of the
dormitory.
By eight thirty the busy intersection in front of
the dormitory was deserted, save occasional police
motorcycles that flashed through the night. The students already had begun to imagine the consequences of
a successful coup d'etat. I might have been deported
from the country, but worse yet, classes at the University of Madrid might have been cancelled in an attempt
to keep the "radical" students from protesting a rightwing takeover. There might have been some sort of
purge of the Communist Party, of which some of my
friends were members. Newspaper editors, writers,
poets, educators, and labor leaders might have been
severely punished. But few dared mention the worst
possible consequence: another Spanish civil war with
the world having to choose sides between a Soviet Left
and a fascist Right.
In response to Tejero's takeover, General Jaime
Milans del Bosch in Valencia placed his southeastern
Spanish province in a state of siege. He suspended all
political and public liberties and prohibited gatherings of
more than four people. Tejero and his Guardia Civil
cronies in Madrid awaited even more military commanders in the provinces to back their operation.

Yet later that night King Juan Carlos I dealt a
blow to the usurpers when he appeared on Spanish
television. Outfitted in his complete military garb to
emphasize his role as chief of the armed forces, he
refused to succumb to the ultraderechistas, the extreme
Right. "The Crown," he announced,"will never tolerate
the forced interruption of the democratic process
decided upon by the Spanish people."
At that I went to bed, totally exhausted after a
day of such tension. The following morning, the dormitory continued to buzz as the students remained glued
to their radios, slurping their cafe and gobbling their
pan. No other province had fallen, and the immediate
threat of danger had passed. By the end of the day,
Tejero was under control, and the government had
restored constitutional order.
The attempted coup even affected the often
out-of-tune americanos. The day following the event,
excitement filled the Instituto Internacional as students
all compared notes and asked each other, "Where were
you when the coup broke out?" Most of us were
concerned about our adopted country and did not want
to see it collapse under the pressure of revolutionary
forces. On the other hand, we recognized our impotence
when we realized that we would be leaving Spain in a
few months. Had the coup been successful, the native
Spaniards—not the visiting American students—would
have had to suffer the consequences of a repressive
regime.
The ordeal was more than perplexing, especially
considering it all happened in Spanish. Comments and
evaluations bombarded me from all sides, but two
questions seemed to recur: One: Colonel Tejera had
previously been involved in an attempted coup in 1978.
He concocted the Galaxy conspiracy in a Madrid cafe in
my neighborhood and called for the seizure and murder
of the first post-Franco president, Adolfo Suarez. The
plans fell through and Tejero escaped with only a mild
slap on the wrist. How could the government allow such
a crackpot to return to active duty in an important
leadership role following such a fiasco? Two: Could a
sudden overthrow of the government occur in the
United States? The Spanish university students were
forever pressing me with this question. My answer was
generally,"No, not like the one Tejero tried to pull off."
I listed several reasons, including the federalist system,
the weakness of the extremist parties, and a long tradition of government stability in the USA.
The attempted coup caught me by surprise, but
contemporary Spanish politics should have led me to
expect drastic measures. Follwoing the 1939 victory of
the Nationalist forces in the Spanish Civil War, General
Francisco Franco established his fascist reign in Spain.

The Dawning Of An Era:
Selective Education?
This week's decision by Wesleyan
University to begin admitting only those
students who are able to pay tuition should
jolt out of insensitivity anyone with
lingering doubts about the seriousness of
government cuts in financial aid.
It's time to remember that the cuts
are the work of one administration, and
that election year 1984 could conceivably
see some of that work undone. For while
it may be that the cuts have performed
some long-overdue trimming of domestic
spending, things have reached the point
where a basic American ideal—the opportunity for advancement via education—is
not merely being threatened but eliminated. It is not simply that the very poor
are losing their shot at quality higher
education, an evil implicit in the cuts from
the outset; the category of the victimized
is growing to include those in higher
economic brackets. Hopkins, for example,
while it has pledged itself not to join
Wesleyan in what appears to be a trend, has
announced a 14 percent tuition hike for
next year. Couple this with the 10 percent
cut in financial aid instituted by the
University this year, and you find that the
student in need of aid is facing what
amounts to a 25 percent jump in tuition.

Thus, while Hopkins may not deny admission to such a student, it very probably will
not be able to extend him the money he
needs to come here.
The point is that the Reagan cuts
have acquired an inexorable media image as
"the beginning of a new era," the end of
the New Deal. While the cuts undeniably
are the beginning of a necessary era of
budget austerity, they must not be allowed
to roll back some of the basic rights safeguarded by the so-called New Deal era.
Perhaps the most important of these rights
is the opportunity for quality higher
education, for a democracy is not a democracy without this most basic form of equal
opportunity.
We are just now starting to hear
about further cuts being contemplated by
the Reagan administration. How much
further can they go before almost no one
can afford a higher education? The first
round of cuts may not have affected many
people you or I know here at Hopkins, but
the next round most certainly will. It
could even be us. And if it's not, we still
don't want to be the last generation of
Americans who had the luxury of expecting to complete a college education.

Spanish buddies were forever trying to pull my leg; yet
he convinced me to listen to the radio broadcasts so that
I could verify the report myself.
Hearing was believing, but all of us that had
gathered around the tiny radio remained extremely
confused. Many students expected all forms of communication to be cut off, yet even in the Cortes itself
both a television camera and a microphone remained to
record the events for the Spanish people.
Reacting like the typically naive Yankee, I
immediately proposed running down to the Cortes to
investigate the situation; but the Spaniards rejected such
rash stupidity. In fact, it was as if they had sixth sense
of what to do in a state of siege. Most of the guys in my
dormitory attempted to telephone their homes in the
provinces to discover if the Guardia Civil had seized
control outside the capital. Those fortunate enough to
own cars filled them with gas and packed suitcases so
they would be able to escape the city if violence were to
erupt. Not a soul dared step outside the confines of the
dormitory.
By eight thirty the busy intersection in front of
the dormitory was deserted, save occasional police
motorcycles that flashed through the night. The students already had begun to imagine the consequences of
a successful coup d'etat. I might have been deported
from the country, but worse yet, classes at the University of Madrid might have been cancelled in an attempt
to keep the "radical" students from protesting a rightwing takeover. There might have been some sort of
purge of the Communist Party, of which some of my
friends were members. Newspaper editors, writers,
poets, educators, and labor leaders might have been
severely punished. But few dared mention the worst
possible consequence: another Spanish civil war with
the world having to choose sides between a Soviet Left
and a fascist Right.
In response to Tejero's takeover, General Jaime
Milans del Bosch in Valencia placed his southeastern
Spanish province in a state of siege. He suspended all
political and public liberties and prohibited gatherings of
more than four people. Tejero and his Guardia Civil
cronies in Madrid awaited even more military commanders in the provinces to back their operation.

Yet later that night King Juan Carlos I dealt a
blow to the usurpers when he appeared on Spanish
television. Outfitted in his complete military garb to
emphasize his role as chief of the armed forces, he
refused to succumb to the ultraderechistas, the extreme
Right. "The Crown," he announced,"will never tolerate
the forced interruption of the democratic process
decided upon by the Spanish people."
At that I went to bed, totally exhausted after a
day of such tension. The following morning, the dormitory continued to buzz as the students remained glued
to their radios, slurping their cafe and gobbling their
pan. No other province had fallen, and the immediate
threat of danger had passed. By the end of the day,
Tejero was under control, and the government had
restored constitutional order.
The attempted coup even affected the often
out-of-tune americanos. The day following the event,
excitement filled the Instituto Internacional as students
all compared notes and asked each other, "Where were
you when the coup broke out?" Most of us were
concerned about our adopted country and did not want
to see it collapse under the pressure of revolutionary
forces. On the other hand, we recognized our impotence
when we realized that we would be leaving Spain in a
few months. Had the coup been successful, the native
Spaniards—not the visiting American students—would
have had to suffer the consequences of a repressive
regime.
The ordeal was more than perplexing, especially
considering it all happened in Spanish. Comments and
evaluations bombarded me from all sides, but two
questions seemed to recur: One: Colonel Tejera had
previously been involved in an attempted coup in 1978.
He concocted the Galaxy conspiracy in a Madrid cafe in
my neighborhood and called for the seizure and murder
of the first post-Franco president, Adolfo Suarez. The
plans fell through and Tejero escaped with only a mild
slap on the wrist. How could the government allow such
a crackpot to return to active duty in an important
leadership role following such a fiasco? Two: Could a
sudden overthrow of the government occur in the
United States? The Spanish university students were
forever pressing me with this question. My answer was
generally,"No, not like the one Tejero tried to pull off."
I listed several reasons, including the federalist system,
the weakness of the extremist parties, and a long tradition of government stability in the USA.
The attempted coup caught me by surprise, but
contemporary Spanish politics should have led me to
expect drastic measures. Follwoing the 1939 victory of
the Nationalist forces in the Spanish Civil War, General
Francisco Franco established his fascist reign in Spain.
